name: Fulton Creek
description:
Introduction

This page describes the upper section of Fulton Creek. This a short and sweet canyon with several scenic rappels. Great for a last day of a weekend trip in the Olympics, or as a full day combined with other canyons in the area.

  • Lower Fulton Creek is separate section of the canyon and has been broken out into its own page. It is possible to run both the upper and lower sections of this creek in one trip, but expect a much longer day out. (See "Middle Fulton" below for more information.) Lower Fulton has about twice the water of Upper Fulton.
  • Watershed: 4.1mi^2. Highest point in the watershed is North Rock at ~4200' elevation.

Approach

Just north of Triton Cove State Park, turn left off Hwy 101 onto Seamount Dr. Follow the road upwards for ~2mi to Jct 969 where there's room for several cars. Note that the road gets very rough after the pavement ends and there are a number of deep drainage berms. High clearance (possibly 4WD) recommended; use extreme caution with 2WD vehicles that you care about.

  • Apparently, a number of canyoneers have been parking at the end of the pavement and either hiking or carpooling up the road. While technically legal to park here, there a number of private homes extremely close by and the presence of cars may cause locals to wonder what you're up to and/or suspect you're up to no good. To alleviate their concerns, it may be better to park 2WD vehicles elsewhere (ex: Triton Cove State Park -- Discovery Pass required) and carpool up to Fulton in a high-clearance vehicle.
  • As of 2022: it is no longer possible to drive down to the drop in. A large berm and ditch barricades the road. You'll need to park at the junction and hike in.

From the junction, just walk down the road to the creek. There is a small campsite at the very end of the road where the old bridge used to be. Just before the campsite, look left to find a motorbike trail leading into the creek. Hike down the creek about 20min to the first rappel.

  • Alternatively, check the map for a shortcut route that drops you in just above the technical section. This cuts off about 0.5mi of hiking.

Descent

DCR = Down Canyon Right

DCL = Down Canyon Left

Use caution as this creek seems unusually slippery. While hiking between rappels, beware leg-eating gaps between rocks that can be hidden under the water.

  • R1: 60' DCL from 2 unlinked bolts into a beautiful amphitheater. DO NOT ADD WEBBING TO THESE BOLTS! Debris from floods can catch on linked bolts and severely damage them. Groups should be familiar with rigging unlinked bolts.
  • R2: 80' from webbing around a log in the center of the creek. There is a small pool in the middle of the rappel.
  • R3: 110' DCR from webbing around a tree that's fallen across the creek. This is a 2-stage rappel with a large pool in the middle. There is a log in the watercourse at the bottom of the second tier which is very easy to avoid while on rappel, but take care when pulling your rope as it can get caught around it.
  • There is a 15' downclimb through a mini-slot shortly after R3.
  • A short distance further down canyon is a large logjam. Downclimb or rappel. For extra bonus points, check out the cool boulder cave on the DCR side of the creek.

Exit

Below the log jam, keep going until it becomes easy to climb out of the creek DCL. If it's steep & brushy, you're in the wrong place. A small cairn marks the exit. Head up into a shallow draw and make your way uphill on game trails to the canyon rim (~300ft gain). The going is relatively easy until you reach the top where the terrain abruptly levels out and you enter an old clear-cut. Do not try to cross the clear-cut directly (it's a serious bushwhack), but instead turn left and follow the along the top of the canyon rim as best you can. It's a little brushy, but not too bad. After a few minutes, pop out on the road and walk back to your car. (2min).

Middle Fulton

For a much longer day, it's possible to continue on down the creek and run Lower Fulton Creek. From the exit described above, it's about a half-mile of typical Olympic creek-walking and rock-hopping. There are several minor downclimbs and a few logjams to climb over / go around / go through. There are two short sections of narrows along the way. The first begins about 300ft downstream of the aforementioned exit. The creek constricts suddenly with a big logjam completely blocking passage.

First Narrows

  • M-R1: 10ft. Climb up onto the logjam and rappel off a log into a short narrows below.
  • Short drop. Downclimb or jump into the next pool.
  • There's an short interesting sequence of pools/channels ahead that looks like it could be fun, but it was barricaded by a strainer in 2022. We bypassed DCR.
  • M-R2: 20ft from log.

Hike about 0.2mi.

Second Narrows

  • Short drop which can be easily downclimbed on the left. Do not jump as the pool is shallow.

On exiting the second narrows, it's about 0.15mi to the entrance of Lower Fulton. Watch for a tributary entering DCR as a sign that you're almost there. Note that the water will about double below this point.

Red tape

Be aware: the parking area, the exit to Upper Fulton, and Middle Fulton are all on private timber company land. Access could be rescinded at any time, so please treat the area with respect and practice your best Leave No Trace.

Beta sites

Trip reports and media

Background

Upper Fulton was first descended by Jake Huddleston, Kevin Steffa, Becca Polglase, Michelle Nilles, and Tiffanie Lin on July 5, 2020.

Middle Fulton was explored by Kevin Clark, Hereward Cooper, and Alex Danielson in Sept 2022.
